title: Some Lessons From Grandma
excerpt: up, my weekends and holidays were all spent the same way.
body:
By Ahana Samat

Growing up, my weekends and holidays were all spent the same way. My parents, both of whom worked full time, even on Saturdays, would drop me off in the morning at my grandmother‚Äôs apartment and pick me up in the evening. This routine became such a way of life for me, that it continued on unquestioned even as a teenager.

Every morning, I would be greeted the same way. ‚ÄúHi Putta,‚Äù she would say, evoking my nickname, her characteristic bindi in the middle of her forehead, and her sari so neatly pinned up, that I often joked that it looked like it had been pleated with a ruler.

In the extensive time I have spent with my grandmother, or Bajju, as everyone calls her, my appreciation for her fierce independence has only grown.

In a small town in India in the 1970s, Bajju, a single mother, worked two jobs as a teacher and a tutor, for what must have been 10 hours a day, to single-handedly sustain her family. She independently financially supported my mother through school, university, and graduate school. All this at a time when most women were afforded little autonomy, and those who seized opportunities and broke glass ceilings were discriminated against systematically.

Very little of my general perspective on life has remained untouched by Bajju. Through leading by example, she has taught me some of the most profound lessons in life, the most important of which helps me manage my finances as a college student.

For starters, she showed me the importance of recording everything I spend. And I mean, EVERYTHING. For as long as I can remember, every time we came back from buying groceries, she would immediately write down the amount she spent in a little notebook. At the time, I didn‚Äôt think much of it, but as I began living on my own, I emulated that habit. While I use an excel sheet to record all my expenses instead of pen and paper, the importance of organization and discipline in having adequate information to make informed fiscal decisions is not lost on me. Sometimes, I am scared to know how much I spend for fear that I have made bad monetary decisions. However, knowing exactly where my money goes helps me cut down on subscriptions, takeout, or Amazon packages when I need to.

But it‚Äôs not just about not wasting money, it‚Äôs also about not wasting things. A rule that Bajju enforced- and that I continue to hold onto- was to never waste food. I never throw away the food I cook, I never take more on my plate than I know I can eat, and I always store leftovers in the freezer for subsequent meals.  Most of my friends and I often say we would save so much money if we stopped eating out. An article by Money Under 30 on the true cost of eating out quantifies this opinion, - actually fact. So, every time I think of ordering in, I also think about whether there is food in my fridge and if I want to waste it. It sounds silly but it‚Äôs saved me so much money!

Why stop at food? Bajju would always recycle glass containers (like those that hold pasta sauce, for example) to hold grains, lentils, or leftovers instead of throwing them away. I recycle all my pasta sauce jars to hold food, stationary, and even act as vases. On a more philosophical level, I have begun to appreciate the variety in utility of every material and how one‚Äôs creativity can add to it.

The core of any endeavor, Bajju has taught me, is the drive to learn. Every afternoon when I visited, Bajju and I would sit beside each other: She would be reading (she is never without a book), and  I would be working on homework. Whenever she comes across a word she does not know, she immediately consults the dictionary to learn what it means. If she is not satisfied with the explanation, she consults the thesaurus.

I apply her example to personal finance. I choose a topic, research it online, and reference several sources before I am satisfied. Sometimes, it is investopedia; sometimes, it is an eBook from my university library: and sometimes, it is my favorite personal finance Instagram account, but I try to make sure I really understand it. The process is never complete - it is comprehensive and exhaustive. But, it is an invaluable lesson in the determination to master a topic and the ambition to succeed.

Admittedly, I may be biased. But, of all the books I have read, podcasts I have listened to, and the research I have done, I have yet to come across a better financial role model than Bajju. An 83 year old woman with a neatly pinned sari who taught me the most valuable lessons I have yet learned in managing my finances and conducting my life.

title: COVID-19 Policy Brief
excerpt: the COVID-19 pandemic, the Effective Reproduction Number ‚Äì Re ‚Äì has been the go-to metric for most government agencies and public health officials.
body:
By OJ SINGH

During the COVID-19 pandemic, the Effective Reproduction Number ‚Äì Re ‚Äì has been the go-to metric for most government agencies and public health officials.

Re is a metric used to gauge the transmissibility of a disease; by calculating Re, governments can implement various intervention strategies, applying them at the degree required, to mitigate the spread of that disease.

Re is determined by three factors: how infectious the infected person is, how many susceptible people the average infector meets in a day, and how many days the infector remains infectious.

The incubation period for the virus is between 5-6 days, however, the recommended range is 1-14 days; this is why many protocols require quarantining for 14 days after coming in contact with an infected person. The average infection period for COVID-19 is 12 days, often starting a few days after symptoms appear.

So, what Re should policymakers aim for in order to effectively manage the pandemic?

When Re is greater than 1, that means that each infected person infects more than one other person; the virus grows exponentially, and Re increases. When Re is less than 1, that means that not every infected person infects someone else.

The goal is to keep Re below 1 ‚Äì this doesn‚Äôt signal a rapid decline in new cases, it signals that with a constant Re below 1, the number of cases per day will slowly decline to 0 over a period of time, as fewer and fewer people are infected.

As mitigation strategies are implemented and uplifted, and individuals interact within unprecedented environments, Re is constantly changing. Government agencies and public health officials should use their area‚Äôs Re to create plans appropriate for their specific circumstances and objectives.

Hugh Murrell and Daniel Murrell, two researchers from South Africa, relied on FinMango‚Äôs South Africa COVID-19 data to create a simple algorithm to calculate Re, so those without in-depth statistical knowledge can understand data and trends in layman‚Äôs terms. They uploaded their technique on GitHub, so that anyone can personalize models and tweak parameters for their specific circumstances. To conduct the industrial-scale algorithms at a fast pace, the researchers switched from using the University of Pretoria‚Äôs data to using FinMango‚Äôs data, as FinMango was accurately publishing granular data in a timely fashion from previously unreported districts.

Using this Re model, policymakers should implement lockdowns, face covering policies, social distancing regulations, curfews, contact tracing, widespread testing, and whatever else is necessary to contain COVID-19.

Some governments, like those of Vietnam and New Zealand, will choose to go into full lockdown and shut down all non-essential activity, conduct extensive contact tracing and widespread testing, and implement travel restrictions to contain the virus and keep it contained.

Other governments, like those of France and Spain, will initially shut down to flatten the curve, and then open back up, after assembling what they believe is necessary medical infrastructure and testing protocols. Recently, both Spain and France have gone back into lockdown. Spain imposed a national curfew to combat its second wave of the virus three days ago. France declared a second national lockdown, as cases soared, this morning.

Whatever policymakers do, ethically, their goal must be to save as many lives as possible.

title: Advocate Spotlight: Dr. Julie Heath
excerpt: by Dylan WestmeyerBackgroundWho is Julie Heath you may ask? First and foremost, Julie Heath is the executive president of the Alpaugh Family economic center and is associated with...
body:
by Dylan Westmeyer

Background

Who is Julie Heath you may ask? First and foremost, Julie Heath is the executive president of the Alpaugh Family economic center and is associated with the University of Cincinnati. Secondly, she is one of the many amazing advocates at FinMango! She became intrigued by economics, but not in the normal sense. She started as a Sociology and Phycology major while minoring in math. While trying to find her calling, she decided to take a Ph.D. program where she was required to take a microeconomics class. Three days into class she fell in love with it. The chair of the economics department was teaching the class and saw the light bulb go off over her head therefore recruiting her to the Ph.D. program in economics and the rest is history. Julia became involved with FinMango after Co-founder and CEO Scott Glasgow reached out to her over LinkedIn.

Education

Julie stated during our interview that the most important skills in economics are curiosity and self-motivation. When one is doing research it is on the person to complete the task at hand and get it published. She also states that looking at a problem in a way that no one has before will also help in achieving goals that were believed to be out of reach. Some skills in the financial education field that would be necessary are empathy and creativity. ‚ÄúHow can we help people who are downright afraid of the topic? How can we help people who aren‚Äôt afraid but have no idea where to look? How can we start young?‚Äù. These are all questions that Dr. Heath states that are fundamental to the furthering of financial education. She then states that financial education is not strictly a high school subject; that it should be taught from a very young age just like Math courses or English courses. Dr. Heath believes that the classes should be captivating and engaging but also have substance. She acknowledges that topics will change throughout the learning process and gives the example that one would not teach a kindergarten class how to write a check or balance a checkbook, but that the students should learn how to think critically and how to think through the costs and benefits to make a good decision. Young students should be taught the costs and benefits of borrowing. She also wishes that young students should learn about opportunity cost. Financial education should be the same as any other subject and not be seen as strictly a high school level class because no other subjects are seen in such a way why should financial education be different.

Career

Dr. Heath and I then spoke about the hardships that she had to go through to become a Professor of Economics and to her, one aspect stood out. Being a woman. Economics is a highly male-dominated field and for Dr. Heath, it was no easy feat to be hired. The first position she earned was at the University of Memphis and was strictly told when she was hired that it was only an affirmative action hire. She did not care though because it was a job and she states that she published more than anyone in her field, but it should not have taken so much for her to rise through the ranks. Dr. Heath believes that to integrate women into the economics field more weight should be placed on alternative ways to answer questions. She goes on to clarify that the Neo-Classical model is very mathematical. There isn‚Äôt much acceptance of describing people‚Äôs behavior or findings of the macroeconomy when there are other valid approaches. She then states that publishing is also very difficult because many publishers reject the work. People must learn to get a thicker skin and also learn how to absorb the criticism; leading to humbling experiences. As a writer, you must be able to pivot because when you put a year and a half into your work and then it gets shot down you must be able to learn what parts to save and what parts to get rid of then move forward.


Debt

We then go on to speak about mistakes that people can make in today‚Äôs economy which are not as noticeable to the people who are not as educated in economics. She states that the main mistake is the accumulation of student debt. ‚ÄúWe know from research that most people when they acquire debt don‚Äôt even know the terms of that debt‚Äù. She then states that it is largely due to colleges making it much easier to accept student loans than it is to deny them. Colleges make it much easier to view student aid packages and just click accept rather than going through extra steps to state that students don‚Äôt want the student loan. She then states that even when students need to take on debt they are unsure of what they need to pay, the length of time and whether it‚Äôs public or private. The mechanics of taking out debt is very confusing. Ohio ranks very high per student per capita of student debt and Dr. Heath states that this is very frustrating because though students may need to take on debt they need to do so with their eyes wide open. She states it‚Äôs so important because when students find out how much they must pay back once they graduate it stops them from spending money as non-indebted adults. These loans cause people to postpone marriage, having children, mortgages, and spending. This then leads to the economy being hurt because it runs on people spending money. Dr. Heath then states that two-thirds of the economy is run on individuals spending money and when debt gets in the way then all of us suffer and the economy doesn‚Äôt grow as it should.

Advice

I finally asked Dr. Heath if she had anything she would like the world to know and she states that the most important concept that she wants people to know is the concept of opportunity cost. She wishes that when people are deciding to pick option A that they are not doing options B through Z and is it worth it? She then states that people make decisions on a knee-jerk reaction and if they would just slow down and think through the implications of their choices they would make better decisions. If implications are unknown then go do research and find out what they are. Then people would make much smarter decisions. She believes that the  Finacial meltdown of 2008 would have been much less severe if people knew the concept much better. The concept is simple but people do not use it as they should.

Dr. Julia Heath is such an amazing advocate (https://finmango.org/dr-julie-heath) and all of us at FinMango would like to thank you for what you are doing. If you would like to become an advocate click this link https://finmango.org/campaign and you will be taken directly to our website.

title: Cultivating Potential to Cultivate Potential- How FinMango Changed my View of Finance
excerpt: by Ahana SamatFor a long time, I envisioned the financial services industry as an endless re-run of ‚ÄúThe Wolf of Wall Street.
body:
by Ahana Samat

For a long time, I envisioned the financial services industry as an endless re-run of ‚ÄúThe Wolf of Wall Street.‚Äù Finance seemed so ruthless, competitive, and masculine. As a woman, I assumed that I could hold a very small place in it. This was despite the fact that I was raised by encouraging parents who owned a small scale business, and family dinners often included asking for my opinion about their work.

Being fairly middle class, finance played a significant role in my life. It became even more important when I looked for scholarships to attend a university in the United States and calculated the expenses of studying abroad. My life revolved around finance yet I claimed I would have nothing to do with it.

In college, I quickly changed my major to Economics. I had no particular rationale for doing this apart from the fact that I enjoyed the subject. But finance was a world apart. So, when I came across the FinMango page on my Instagram, I was surprised. I knew immediately that FinMango was doing important work in promoting personal and economic freedom via financial literacy. They were making people independent and self-sufficient- what could be better? This inspired me when I thought the world of finance had little humanity to offer.

Soon after, I took a leap of faith. I messaged the founder and CEO of FinMango, Scott Glasgow, on Instagram asking if his organization had any volunteer opportunities available for a college student with no experience and an interest, that after months of denial, had revealed itself.

FinMango took me on after we messaged. After two weeks of being a ‚ÄúMango‚Äù, I was already in charge of conducting a panel at our grand ‚ÄúEXTRAVAGANZA‚Äù event, a 24-hour free Zoom call, where people from all walks of life were united in one mission ‚Äì to promote financial literacy. Specifically, I conducted a panel discussion on the importance of financial literacy for women in the world of business. As I prepared for the panel, I felt a bit like an imposter. I used to view finance as a very male-dominated field, but here I was, talking to women pioneers in venture capital, risk management, and corporate law. My belief that finance was a place that I didn't belong was shattered. I wasn't disappointed to be wrong.

A topic that came up in the panel was the low number of women represented in the financial services industry and the relative invisibility of those who were. We also talked a lot about confidence. This struck me on a very personal level. Despite successfully navigating a very quantitative- heavy major, I didn‚Äôt feel confident in my abilities to handle finance or numbers. In this panel, as well as conversations I have had with my peers, there is agreement that women are socialized into being nice and modest, often at the expense of their confidence. The lack of this quality can infiltrate our careers and the way we view finance.

Developing this innate confidence also depends on the community one is surrounded by. At FinMango, I have been given opportunities that strengthened my belief in my ability to make a change. One prominent example of this is the Google collaboration, an open source data project designed to collect information about the COVID-19 pandemic. I worked with a team that supported my outlook and encouraged my leadership in a world that often tells women otherwise. Additionally, the internal training opportunities for volunteers have led me to meet some of the most fascinating leaders in fields of marketing and corporate law, who have mentored me and shared their knowledge, skills, and external resources to help me succeed in the business world. To say I am one of the lucky few is an understatement.

Women are underrepresented in the financial services industry, are less likely to be financially literate, yet, according to an article by The Economist, women were expected to control $72 trillion of the world‚Äôs wealth by 2020, as estimated in 2015. The number of women represented in the financial services industry is growing, as companies promise equal representation. But it shouldn‚Äôt stop there ‚Äì the goal is to ensure equity through visibility. Women should not just have a seat at the table; their voice and professional opinions should be accorded equal legitimacy as their male peers. Workforces should encourage the confidence of women, rather than subscribing to archaic societal norms of meekness.

The FinMango community, the resources it has provided me with, and my personal experiences convince me that I can help drive change. By building my confidence and providing me with endless opportunities, FinMango has changed the way I view finance, my place in it as a woman, and has shown me what I can do to help those who come after me. It has inspired me to follow my passion of increasing financial literacy among women and making the financial services industry more representative. But equality- true equality- can only exist when it is not limited to pockets and available to a ‚Äúlucky few‚Äù but is an indisputable fact of life for all. I believe that financial literacy can aid in this goal.

title: Carolyn Cooper: from Silicon Valley to the Classroom
excerpt: by Erinn HeffesCarolyn Cooper is a Certified Public Accountant, a Financial Educator and a Coach with professional experience and a passion for creating productive lives that...
body:
by Erinn Heffes

Carolyn Cooper is a Certified Public Accountant, a Financial Educator and a Coach with professional experience and a passion for creating productive lives that inspire growth and independence in young people.She immigrated to San Jose, California from Kuwait when she was 13 years old. A major reason for this move was to afford her the opportunity of an education because opportunities for women were limited in Kuwait at that time. Despite taking an accounting class in high school and thoroughly enjoying it, she realized that she was not taught personal finance. While attending UC Santa Barbara, Cooper studied Business Economics with an emphasis in Accounting. She took part in a class that introduced a sliver of consumer economics; living on your own, creating a budget, renting an apartment, buying a car etc. Asides from this class, most of Cooper‚Äôs finance knowledge was self-taught. She came across a radio station that discussed personal finance and investing and through simply listening to this station while driving back and forth from school, Cooper educated herself on personal finance. Cooper eventually ended up pursuing a career in Public Accounting and as soon as she got her first job, she invested in a 401k plan and opened up her IRA account at the same time.

When her daughters were growing up, she observed that they were not being taught anything on finance and Cooper says she observed that many of the classes she took on personal finance no longer existed. Cooper believed that this was a necessary class her daughters should be taking and a topic they needed to be educated on. Cooper shared an entry with me from 2013 from her journal, while attending a ‚Äúback to school night‚Äù for her daughters where parents were being informed on specific content and aspects. In her journal Cooper wrote about an ‚Äòaha‚Äô moment she had on personal finance and wondered why they were not educating young individuals on personal finance from high school. Cooper, realizing that most of her financial knowledge was self-taught and that not only her daughters but her friends, employees and peers did not have the necessary financial knowledge they actually needed and was available, Cooper realized there was a serious need that had to be fulfilled.  Cooper had a successful career in Silicon Valley and was able to save and invest with her husband for years. This allowed her the ability to stop working and rekindle her passion for teaching and educating others, specifically on financial literacy.

Throughout her research, Cooper came across Next Gen Personal Finance and began taking classes with them. She began teaching before the COVID-19 pandemic and like many she did now allow her plan and passion to be derailed and she has continued teaching via Zoom classes. Cooper says that, ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt a job‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a dream. THE dream job‚Äù If there was one thing that Cooper wishes someone told her when she was younger, it is the importance of honing your soft skills; being more open, volunteering, public speaking and simply putting yourself out there. Cooper incorporates these skills from early in her classes so that students are prepared for when their professional careers develop. Asides from public speaking and networking, Cooper believes that one major skill that is necessary in this area is behavioral finance and practicing living within your means. Cooper says, ‚ÄúIt is not just the actual skills of literally here is a spreadsheet and you start filling it out‚Ä¶there is a lot of behavioral finance that goes into it.‚Äù There is more to finance than dollars and cents and Cooper wants to help people to understand this. While behavioral finance is a major skill Cooper believes needs to be pushed, she also believes this is the major issue in terms of financial literacy. The notion of not really understanding what it is and not having these foundational skills.

Cooper says that we would never give a 16 year old the keys to a car without the proper driving certifications, so why would we give them the keys to everything as soon as they turn 18, with no training. At the age of 18, one can open a bank account, sign up for credit cards etc. all on their own, yet they frequently lack the education to support these processes properly. She says that COVID has created great awareness and there is now a momentum and everyone simply has to do their share. Cooper is extremely passionate about this issue and providing access to this knowledge to all. As a result, Cooper‚Äôs classes are not necessarily non-profit nor are they ‚Äòfor business.‚Äô She does charge for some classes, but believes this helps to build accountability and attendance. Cooper does offer some classes for free and waives fees. She really wants to teach and for it to be affordable. She wants everyone to have that access and believes the earlier they have this access the better.

Carolyn is an incredible advocate (Advocate Profile) and all of us at FinMango would like to thank you for what you are doing. Click this link if you want to become a FinMango advocate: https://finmango.org/campaign.

title: Flight of the Purple Martins: FinMango‚Äôs Story
excerpt: As told by Jon LiA summer in Suburban Ohio.
body:
As told by Jon Li

A summer in Suburban Ohio. What do you think of? If you‚Äôre not from these parts, I‚Äôm guessing you‚Äôre thinking of endless rows of corn basking in steady heat and backyard bonfires fueled by Budlight and Swenson‚Äôs. If you are from here‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre probably thinking that my description is pretty accurate. And while Ohio does in fact offer an abundance of Midwest charm it also marks the beginning of my journey with FinMango.

Looking past the dullness of where I come from, a pristine reservoir called Nimisila teeters on the border of Stark County and Summit County. To me, Nimisila served many purposes throughout the years. In high school, my friends and I would come here and  be degenerates. The summer after I graduated, I‚Äôd run on the splatter of trails next to Nim to soothe myself and marinate  in my thoughts. Then came summer 2016 - my first summer home from college. Scott started inviting me to kayak on the reservoir. At that time, I thought nothing more of it, he was a workout friend who I‚Äôd played tennis with since high school.  

As the summer progressed, our conversations while paddling around on the kayaks kept turning towards this idea he had for a nonprofit called FinMango - a foundation that would  address the inequitable access to financial literacy throughout the world. Well, I figured, ‚ÄúWhy the hell not?‚Äù I quickly jumped aboard this opportunity to give back to the community at large by starting something of my own. On a smaller but just as meaningful scale,  I had started a STEAM nonprofit in high school that reached hundreds of students. That experience made the idea of helping thousands, if not hundreds of thousands or even millions of people a lot more fathomable.

This simple burning desire to create and volunteer led to many sunburnt afternoons spent discussing the concept on Nim. Somehow, these kayaks turned out to be the first boardroom, and the beating sun was our Zoom background before Zoom was even mainstream. Early phone calls made by Scott and I often came while we were on the water. Somehow, we‚Äôd have to figure out how to make sense of the ideas that floated across the (nonexistent) waves. Like the sky above us during those times, there truly wasn‚Äôt a limit.

Fast forward to September, 2020. We‚Äôre in the middle of a pandemic and consequently, I had spent my first summer home since the one in  2016. Scott and I are again kayaking on Nimisila. As we‚Äôre paddling into the middle of the reservoir, we wonder why so many people are in the water and what dozens of spectators had anxiously put up lawn chairs to witness. What Scott and I were about to witness is a perfect, but admittingly cheesy, analogy to where FinMango has progressed since its inception 4 years prior.

The purple martins emerged from the horizon. They came in black streaks all while somehow creating a harmonious cacophony. Seemingly endless waves kept gliding past us in disjointed patterns until they would suddenly create a beautifully symmetric vortex. To us, their flight trajectories seemed to make no sense, until it did. Again and again, the smattering of birds across the sky would collect more of their brethren and then orchestrate symphonic tornados. The finale was the last vortex of birds, perfectly choreographed and synchronized. The great fall migration had begun.

Much like the purple martins, FinMango came from a conglomeration of ideas. Waves of fresh inspiration came from journals, conferences, and long conversations. Thousands of hours of work had been put into a variety of different projects by hundreds of volunteers, forming these successful vortexes that validated the original concept. But, we‚Äôre now at an inflection point. I know we‚Äôre at the same stage as the last vortex of the purple martins, where everything is now coming together. We always had this grandiose vision, but as an organization, we now understand how we‚Äôre going to fly onto the big stage and what we need to get there. Through calculated miracles, we‚Äôve managed to make sense of the beautiful cacophony (by separating our work into 3 pillars: Data, Tech, and Advocacy), and now we‚Äôre ready to migrate.

title: Fruits From The Mango Tree
excerpt: by Bruna Ch√≠xaroIt's only been a few months since I was invited to join FinMango, a global financial inclusion nonprofit, as a volunteer team member to work on the COVID-19 Open...
body:
by Bruna Ch√≠xaro

It's only been a few months since I was invited to join FinMango, a global financial inclusion nonprofit, as a volunteer team member to work on the COVID-19 Open Data Project. However, it‚Äôs been enough time to learn a great deal about dedication, teamwork, healthy leadership behavior, and, most important of all, empathy.

I have been observing each team member, internally known as ‚ÄúMango,‚Äù and their particular skills. From day one, I have been amazed by their individual abilities, that when combined together as a team, allow them to unite people together around a common goal, and bring out the best in one another. Our group is a great example of people who have not lost empathy for others, during these difficult times of the pandemic. After all, this has been a difficult year for all people, as the COVID-19 has left no country untouched.

I believe the current pandemic has instilled in the Mangoes the importance of practicing kindness, not only toward others, but also themselves. The volunteer team has shown the whole world the important role that financial literacy plays in the life of every individual. Not only have the repercussions of COVID-19 created a public health crisis, they have also indicated that the lack of financial education can contribute to greater social issues.

Two years ago, I came across FinMango on Instagram; I was in my first year of specializing in Human Rights and International Law, and started following the nonprofit to learn more about the important aspects of financial education for the global community. Since then, I have observed how passionate and determined FinMango is in pursuing their mission of ending the problem of financial exclusion by integrating values like compassion, empathy and cooperation.

Beyond the pandemic, it is important to reflect upon the current global economic model which is based on uninterrupted growth, waste, and unsustainable consumerism. Specifically, this pandemic calls on every person to rethink with solidarity about the possibilities for sustainable life globally, and to participate in building a more cooperative, and empathic society. It is crucial that each person tries to the best of their ability, to put empathy into action throughout the world.

In this aspect, each Mango, in their particular way, has been a true role model for me, and I am truly grateful for that.

title: How Passion Creates a Domino Effect: The Role of Interpersonal Uplifting in the FinLit World
excerpt: My name is Anthony Schilt, volunteer lead of public relations and communications at FinMango, a non-profit organization whose goal is to solve the problem of global income...
body:
My name is Anthony Schilt, volunteer lead of public relations and communications at FinMango, a non-profit organization whose goal is to solve the problem of global income inequality through financial literacy. FinMango has a unique and riveting start-up story. Focusing on data, technology, and advocacy to solve the problem of financial exclusion, we help others realize their true potential by igniting a world of opportunity.

Instead of talking about these key components in depth, ‚Äì and how important each of them are, this blog will bring into focus what makes FinMango‚Äôs volunteers, internally known as ‚Äúmangos,‚Äù so creative and passionate.  

My journey with FinMango began in December 2019. One day in early December, I was casually scrolling through LinkedIn. I only had five connections (most of whom were family members), no practical experience related to my studies, and a lack of understanding for what career I wanted to pursue. I was looking at other people‚Äôs profiles, jealous of what I saw, until a certain brand caught my eye. The person I was stalking on LinkedIn was involved in FinMango.

Have I heard about this somewhere before? After looking into FinMango‚Äôs page on LinkedIn, I knew almost immediately that I might have found ‚Äúit.‚Äù I loved the cause, and was majoring in Finance; these two ‚Äòpros‚Äô were good enough for me. I was a freshman trying to build up my resume after all. So, I reached out to this person, scheduled a one-on-one, and planned to meet with them later that same day for an interview.

On my way there, I was trembling; my hands were sweating and I was anxious about how I‚Äôd perform. I was, as they say, a hot mess. Ultimately, my nerves settled down due to my interviewer‚Äôs energetic persona. I admired his passion. He was a fellow student at OSU. I would later come to find out that this virtue ‚Äì being passionate ‚Äì was the foundation that FinMango thrived on.

Although I was noticeably nervous, he saw past that, and asked about my strengths and abilities. This meant a lot to me. It signaled the nurturing and supportive environment that fuels creativity inside our organization. After the interview, I was told that I would hear back soon from one of the leaders. Soon after, I had the opportunity to speak over the phone with Scott Glasgow, the Founder and Chief Executive Officer of FinMango.

When Scott initially contacted me via text, I smiled. It was almost 2:00 A.M.; he was a night owl, just like me. Scott explained to me how he and the other night owls at FinMango are constantly communicating, working on progressive initiatives, or brainstorming about the next big thing. I knew that I would be one of them. I don‚Äôt know. It‚Äôs just something about the nighttime that gets me motivated to work. If that‚Äôs how the CEO operates, maybe I‚Äôm doing something right.

We had spoken together over the phone that night, and just before we ended the call, I noticed that it had lasted over an hour. I was blown away; it felt like 15 minutes. At half-past, 3:00 AM, I was standing in front of the mirror with the biggest smile on my face I‚Äôve had in awhile. I told myself not to get too excited, though, since I wasn‚Äôt officially a part of this just yet.

In the following days, Scott introduced me to Gemma Bosch Martinez, FinMango‚Äôs Chief Knowledge Officer. Gemma lives in Spain, a country I have always wanted to travel to, so I was ecstatic to speak with her about her experiences there. I love learning about Spanish language and culture, so having this global connection with someone immersed in the culture was really cool.

One of my greatest ‚ÄúFinMemories,‚Äù in fact, was when I spoke with Gemma for the first time, and I found out that I wasn‚Äôt as good as I thought I was at conversational Spanish. It was hilarious, and a great learning experience. It was the small, seemingly insignificant moments like these that made the greatest memories at FinMango. Meeting all of these amazing leaders, students and bosses alike, combined with the opportunity to make an impact in the world, left me with profuse excitement. I was ready to get started.

Getting started:

I began working on my very first project, a collaboration with KUBUKA, an organization focused on developing vulnerable communities in Kenya and Zambia. After reading my instructions from Gemma, I had a feeling that this ‚Äúgetting-started project‚Äù wasn‚Äôt exactly about getting started. Instead, it was about providing a positive economic impact right away. I got a feel for the work I would be doing beforehand, and appreciated that greatly. I was intimidated, but I was more so eager to learn, and that eagerness overtook the intimidation I felt.

So, what was my task? ‚Äî To co-create an educational presentation tool (with resources) that would take place over three weeks. The program taught 100 children and adults about Financial Literacy and Entrepreneurship. Wow.

While I worked on the project, I struggled, as I expected, but I asked questions and was able to overcome those struggles. Since many projects fail at non-profit organizations, I was congratulated for having a successful first project ‚Äî something not many mangos have the opportunity to experience.

I was overjoyed to receive such feedback on my work. The team was impressed with the content I produced, and the program was implemented in Zambia later that month (pictured below). This accomplishment spurred self-confidence that I had been lacking, and helped me understand how I can combat my depression and anxiety by helping others and making an impact.

Operation Extravaganza:

I was promoted to ‚ÄúCreative Marketing Intern‚Äù after this project. The first initiative I took part in during my internship ‚Äì The FinMango Extravaganza ‚Äì became an integral part of FinMango‚Äôs story. The Extravaganza, hosted virtually in May 2020, was a 24-hour live webinar that took place over Zoom, and featured 50+ successful keynote speakers. I was co-coordinator of technology for the event, alongside Uday Patel and Kishan Patel. For the first 12 hours, covering the United States, Uday, Kishan, and I hosted the webinar nonstop. But nothing great lasts forever, right?

When logistical problems arose,  our team had to combat them efficiently‚Äîfailure was simply not an option. One of our issues was actually having too many people, as ironic as that sounds. A celebrity, who will remain unnamed, posted our event link, which led to an overwhelming influx of Zoom viewers. When hundreds of people joined, they saw our CEO speaking. In a matter of seconds, everyone changed their name to ‚ÄúScott Glasgow,‚Äù or ‚ÄúScott Glasgow #2, or #3‚Äù  and so on, which was quite funny for onlookers, but a disaster for the three of us manning technology! Once we figured out the technical issues, however, we had a smooth rhythm. Of course, we still had our laughs at the hundreds of Scott Glasgows joining our webinar.

It would be impudent not to highlight how the logistics were pulled-off; I want to underscore the intricate efforts of two mangos in particular: Uday Patel, a sophomore at The Ohio State University studying information systems management, and Kishan Patel, a junior at The Ohio State University studying Finance.

I was lucky enough to play the role for Uday that Ben, my interviewer for FinMango, played for me. In late February of 2020, I had a conversation with Uday about FinMango‚Äôs mission and why he should be excited. After our conversation, he had a similar realization ‚Äî he immediately saw the intrinsic value of being a ‚Äúmango.‚Äù Two weeks later, Uday spoke with Kishan Patel about FinMango and its goals. Kishan became a marketing and technology intern in early April. And so starts the ultra critical uplifting domino-effect.

Extravaganza was launched the month after Uday and Kishan were onboarded. They adapted to a mammoth challenge immediately, learning along the way to overcome every obstacle we faced! The FinMango leadership was in awe of our accomplishments. What was significant about this experience, though, was that I had unknowingly found my niche, as did Uday and Kishan. Personally, I found out how rewarding it was to build a team, communicate, and uplift in a way that led us all to success. Uday and Kishan found that they wanted to pursue technology and data-focused volunteering, which they have made tremendous strides in: they learned the logistics of Google Cloud, Google Data Studio, and Tableau, while simultaneously inputting data for the K-12 covid data initiative within FinMango‚Äôs Data Project. Now, like me, Uday and Kishan are ‚Äúmango fellows,‚Äù a status given to those who demonstrate proven commitment to FinMango and its cause over time.

Once Extravaganza was over, the weight of the moment hit; our leaders shed tears. A group of student mangos pulled off something this great with one secret weapon ‚Äì passion.

Our team mapped out this idea, planned accordingly, assembled a group of over 50 professionals and keynote speakers, and accidentally broke the world record for the world‚Äôs longest Zoom call. Little did we know that the Extravaganza event set the stage for everything FinMango will accomplish later on. It also subconsciously worked wonders for everyone‚Äôs personal and professional development.

How we ‚Äúmango‚Äù during the pandemic:

The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted the lives of billions around the globe. Just about everyone has been affected by the virus in one way or another. It breaks my heart to think about the lives lost and impacted, and I wish the best to those affected by the virus in health, financially, or otherwise.

Instead of standing idly by on the sidelines, we knew we had to do something. FinMango made the humanitarian cause surrounding COVID-19 a short-term priority alongside our long-term goal of diminishing financial exclusion. When we launched the FinMango Data Project, I didn‚Äôt know what to expect. I was nervous. However, Now was the time to make an impact on real people, as real lives are at stake. This urgency keeps our mangos sharp and focused when they conduct this work.

Two main initiatives are at the heart of FinMango‚Äôs Data Project:

  1. FinMango‚Äôs contributions to the Google COVID-19 Open Data Project
  2. ‚Äúthecovidmonitor.com‚Äù ‚Äì Researching COVID-19 outbreaks data in K-12 schools across the United States, and providing real-time accurate reporting and transparency

I took charge of managing social media for @TheCOVIDMonitor on Twitter and Instagram; a seemingly easy task. I have the pleasure of reading through countless tweets, replies and comments from people looking for a rise out of FinMango. I have even received some questionable direct messages on my personal accounts. I actually love everything about this; at FinMango, haters are, in fact, our motivators.

Alongside my responsibilities for our Data Project, I was responsible for all applicant hiring. I am especially careful when seeking out potential mangos. I ensure they (1) are genuinely interested, (2) understand our mission and why it is an issue, and (3) are likely to positively contribute to our greater cause. Many students ask me about FinMango so they can put it on their resume; the fact of the matter is, at FinMango, we don‚Äôt make room for those who don‚Äôt make room for us. Oh, and we also don‚Äôt make room for those who don‚Äôt wear masks and practice social distancing.

Over the Fall, I sought to speak to other students on campus at the Ohio State University about both the COVID pandemic and financial exclusion crisis. I found my passion for our mission almost one year ago, and maybe that‚Äôs why I have the ability to get others to FinMango like I do. Being immersed in such a supportive, progressive environment at FinMango has only benefited me positively.

So, from mid-August to the end of October, I have been successful in seeking out, interviewing and onboarding five outstanding new mangoes. These talented individuals include: (1) Kevin D‚ÄôSouza, who is naturally attentive to detail and always performs beyond expectations. (2) Bryce Chappelear, who input essential K-12 covid data at the last-minute per our CEO‚Äôs request and successfully saved the day. (3) Esha Sharma, who has an innate ability to multitask, pioneering FinMango‚Äôs first ever internally produced merchandise collection. (4) Dylan Forman and (5) Sam Holtzapple, who have only been involved for a few weeks‚Äô time, have already collaborated with me in producing several videos that have been published since on our website. I could not have been happier with these wonderful mangos, who have also come to be some of my best friends.

October 27, 2020

title: Here is why full-grown adults, who should know better, are opening schools, and why that sucks
excerpt: coronavirus pandemic has had a seismic impact on every aspect of our lives.
body:
By OJ SINGH

The coronavirus pandemic has had a seismic impact on every aspect of our lives. From frequenting gyms and restaurants, to attending social events with friends and family; events we once took for granted have revealed themselves to be privileges.

A wide range of industries have been impacted during the pandemic, and now institutions of higher education, and the environments surrounding them, face a unique intersection of challenges.

Universities and colleges are massive social hubs  where  students come together from around the world to engage in educational and social activities that heavily influence their character development. College towns, communities built around institutions of higher education that support countless university members and affiliates, are financially suffering along with the academic institutions they support.

College students, typically between 18-23 years of age, have a lower mortality rate from COVID-19, but are very likely to asymptotically transmit the virus to more vulnerable populations, like older university staff and professors, immunocompromised students, and many other people in the broader campus bubble. The attached New York Times map visually represents the extent of community spread in college campuses around the United States.

The data below shows estimated active cases in Alachua County, Florida, home of the University of Florida, which has a student body of around 60,000 students as of 2019.

Can you guess when in-person college classes resumed?

Young people are not invincible. Even if they survive Covid, there is a high probability of sustaining permanent organ damage, the full extent of which is still unknown.

The question is why are administrative personnel at institutions of higher learning , who have known since April, 2020 about both the exponential spread of the virus and the national Covid testing shortage, pushing to open campuses?

An NBC College Financial Health report outlines before the pandemic, how universities were already financially struggling due to declining enrollment rates, and dwindling governmental budgetary support. Private institutions, some with sizable endowments, still rely heavily on tuition, donations, and other revenue (sponsored research, hospital wings, etc.). Losses are covered by institutional revenue and endowments,  and are later recovered through increases in tuition and fees.

With the possibility of another recession allegedly looming, public institutions, largely funded by state subsidies, are anticipating budget shortfalls, and have already begun cutting academic programs. The 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Acts weakened government revenue retention, and further increased the federal deficit, which was compensated for by cutting an already depleted education budget. With necessary emergency spending for unemployment benefits, small business bailouts, and increasing healthcare costs, it is unlikely that the education budget will receive a larger portion of  government revenue when tax revenue is projected to fall sharply due to the virus.

A major reason for reopening (or at least trying to reopen) institutions of higher education seems to be financial.

Many schools, large and small, public and private, have tried one of the following strategies: online-only instruction, hybrid instruction, and in-person instruction.

In early June, Harvard announced that it will be online-only for the 2020-21 academic year,  and will invite up to 40% students to live on campus. Others changed course while implementing a strategy; University of Notre Dame and University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill closed down within two weeks of resuming in-person instruction because of clusters of infections arising from campus parties. Michigan State University moved to online-only instruction days before their hybrid reopening, after realizing that any in-person instruction was not feasible due to lack of medical infrastructure necessary to support routine testing of thousands of students  in order to contain outbreaks.

Some schools soldiered on with in-person classes, even though infections spiked.

The University of Georgia and the University of Alabama remain committed to in-person instruction, despite over 3,500 and 2,500 students testing positive respectively for the virus. Georgia Tech students staged a ‚Äúdie-in‚Äù on the first day of class to protest the university‚Äôs safety standards.

The Southeastern Conference (SEC) and other conferences are allowing  tens of thousands of fans into football stadiums, where guidelines for social distancing and face covering are not strictly enforced. It is important to note that athletic revenue is a multifaceted  benefit for schools. When athletic teams perform well, student applications rise, and everyone makes millions, except for the athletes themselves..

One may ask, what is the ‚Äúnet gain‚Äù? Is it time to rethink for-profit only higher education? If institutions of higher learning have been aware of the risk of bringing students back, but have been allowing preventable negative ramifications to occur by holding in-person classes to justify charging the same rate of tuition anyways, clearly, the purpose of offering a higher education has been lost a while ago.

It is one thing to say that we have to live with the virus until there is a vaccine, but it is not ethical  to disregard common sense precautions and create an environment that easily allows the virus to spread.

University administrators with collective decades of experience in higher education, are shifting blame for infection clusters onto 18-23 year old students for partying, when adults with immense life experience, who are culpable for bringing students back, should simply know better. This does not absolve students of responsibility, and those who break rules should be disciplined. However, administrators cannot expect to invite socially-starved students back to school, believing that all students will comply with the rules, and that there will be no unintended consequences, not fully grasping the fact it only takes one person to start an outbreak.

The fallacy of sunk cost, a cost that has already been incurred and is unable to be recovered, employed by administrators of institutions of higher learning is harming  thousands of college  students each day. The United States is likely entering its third peak of the first wave of infections.  Over 220,000 people are dead, and many who survive face long-term health complications.  

I hate writing about the pandemic in economic terms. To me, the simple fact that people are dying is sufficient for change. In exchange for short-term ‚Äúgains,‚Äù decision-makers are creating environments that will allow several negative health effects to occur among the population, that will prolong the current crisis: the potential for a permanently incapacitated labor force, lack of hospital beds for the severely ill, and unending negative economic impact, due to consistent high positivity rates of Covid that will continue to keep multiple industries closed or operating at low capacity, without a plan for long-term recovery in sight.

There is no net gain. However, that does not mean that we choose the road that leads to the most negative consequences.

title: How the Pandemic Inspires Me to Build Resilience Around the World
excerpt: There‚Äôs something that happens when adversity strikes that changes the way you look at life.
body:
By Scott Glasgow

There‚Äôs something that happens when adversity strikes that changes the way you look at life. This year, I was lucky enough to overcome that adversity with resilience‚Äîthe ability to absorb, adapt, and transform.

It‚Äôs crazy to think about how different things were just a few months ago. I was working 80+ hours a week, jumping on flights to speak around the world, and not understanding the concept of work-life balance. FinMango had little focus and I was struggling to keep it all together.

But today, I got to look back on a year of wins, losses and learning and take comfort in the fact that we didn‚Äôt ever run out of money, and we did manage to mostly keep it all together. And thanks to a few lucky breaks‚Äîlike smashing a world record, launching a collaboration with Google, and gaining national media coverage‚Äîwe‚Äôre now focused and jumping into an incredible future.

With the year quickly coming to a close, I‚Äôm motivated to work harder than ever to solve the financial exclusion problem. FinMango can now be defined by three words: Data, Tech, and Advocacy. You can read more about the pivot here.

While I‚Äôm grateful for how radically different my life has changed during the pandemic compared to the average person, recognizing this is a reminder of how important it is to use the privilege and opportunities we are given to help those around us.

At FinMango, all we do is give. We give people the opportunity to influence the world, to work on projects that save lives, and be a part of something bigger. Much bigger.

And in our lives, we‚Äôre only given so many opportunities to do things like that ... most never even get the chance.

Overall, this year has taught me so much about resilience. All of the failures, successes, hopes, dreams, and disappointments that I have experienced have turned into important life lessons. I‚Äôve learned about the importance of giving and of radical generosity. I‚Äôve learned about integrity, respect, and kindness. I‚Äôve tried to be generous with my time and I‚Äôve tried to be of service to others. And as I look forward to the next few years, I can only hope that all these lessons I‚Äôve learned can be used to help spur the potential of tens of millions more people around the world.

We have a lot of work ahead and we need to raise a lot of money to make it happen, but I feel grateful for 2020. I‚Äôve been given the opportunity of a lifetime and I‚Äôm running with it. I might be wrong, but I think the FinMango story has just begun‚Ä¶ Let‚Äôs jump on the train!

Stay tuned and learn how to support our work at finmango.org.

title: How Unity and Passion Can Change the World: My Data Internship Experience with FinMango
excerpt: by Rebeca LozanoAfter being evacuated from Brazil, during what was supposed to be my year-long and fascinating experience in a country I had longed to visit, I felt troublingly...
body:
by Rebeca Lozano

After being evacuated from Brazil, during what was supposed to be my year-long and fascinating experience in a country I had longed to visit, I felt troublingly out of place. Plans suddenly changed, not only within my program, but within school, work, and among my friends, and family. Upon my return to the United States, I could not help but think about my month and a half experience in Brazil. More intensely, I could not help but think of some of the moments that shook me to my core ‚Äì from witnessing theft in an appliance store, a man beaten in the streets by the police for stealing a phone, and to being pickpocketed on my walk back to my apartment.

I kept thinking about the huge contrast between my life in Texas and in Minas Gerais regarding their levels of safety and crime rates, and I constantly thought about how my daily routine changed dramatically once in Brazil. Inevitably, I began to think of the why. Why is the level of safety tragically lower? Why can‚Äôt I walk to the corner store without being overly-aware of my surroundings, what I‚Äôm wearing, or where I have my phone, wallet, and keys?

It is easy to highlight the many things that enable the level of insecurity.  However, my initial thought was the inaccessibility of economic resources to communities, such as the lack of well paid employment, the lack of financial literacy, and the inability of the government to help the poor.

Fast-forward to a couple of days being back in the U.S.,I was settled in my college apartment in Austin, Texas, and I began to think of ways in which I could provide immediate help to improve access to economic resources in any shape or form, big or small. I was already overwhelmed simply with the idea of helping, wondering where to start, especially considering we were in the middle of a pandemic. I thought there may not be opportunities to help in the slightest. One evening, as I was scrolling through Instagram photos with the hashtag ‚Äú#financial literacy,‚Äù I came across FinMango‚Äôs page. I was captivated by the colors and the bio that quickly phrased ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre on a mission to solve the financial exclusion problem..‚Äù. I applied to volunteer not really knowing what to expect, what I would specifically be working on, or what I needed to know, but needless to say I was excited.

A couple days later, Scott gave me a call and mentioned this COVID-19 Data Project. He summarized what the project would entail, gathering geographical data on this fast-changing virus no one really knows much about. Even though I knew this did not directly have much to do with financial literacy, I knew it was a way in which I could help FinMango and thus, support its mission. A team of about 10 people was formed. Our team consisted of high-schoolers, college students, a pharmacist, a professor, an engineer, and our great CEO, Scott. It is easy to say that with this dynamic, and the level of expertise, I was a bit skeptical of how efficient we would be. I was curious to see how a couple of college and high school students would be able to contribute to a project of this magnitude. I felt like 10 individuals were about to take over the world‚Äôs COVID-19 data ‚Äì clearly exciting.

We began designing a structure. We organized where our data would go, set up several calls per week, and searched for reliable sources from health organizations that appropriately met our expectations in credibility and accuracy. This was a challenge. I was now reading and browsing extensively for sources that seemed reliable. We also came to realize there were many countries that lacked reporting daily or weekly. However, after what felt like a couple of days, we began finding these ‚Äúgold mines‚Äù of data and got to work. For weeks I went from digging for sources, updating the data routinely, meeting with our team, and sharing our successes and challenges on a weekly basis.

Celebrating our work, we knew we could take on more. We were then introduced to the idea of contributing to a dataset focused on K-12 districts across the U.S. My initial thought was that this would be easier than searching for resources with COVID-19 data from across the globe. I thought, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the U.S. There must be many people collecting K-12 data. Outbreaks in schools are crucial to track. This should be easy.‚Äù

But, I was very wrong. To my surprise this data collection proved itself to be even more difficult, which was shocking. I soon came to realize that data accessibility was extraordinarily limited for several states in the Southeast region. There were also states that still were not reporting outbreaks and cases, even though it was clear from the news that cases were rising nationwide with classes resuming across specific districts. I was worried and questioned why such numbers were not being reported when these are facts anyone should have access to, especially those attending and working in schools in these districts. I kept coming across news articles for weeks that said, ‚ÄúSo and so state does not have a COVID-19 dataset nor dashboard for their school districts, but reported they will be releasing one soon.‚Äù

While this was rather devastating to encounter, we surpassed our own expectations and standards for the states that were actively reporting on K-12 cases and outbreaks. Our team (now slightly bigger than when we started) continuously worked to get The COVID Monitor up and running with the data available. We shared these victories during our weekly meetings and work sessions ‚Äì and soon enough, we were featured on the NY Times, CNN, The Vox, and simultaneously skyrocketing on Twitter thanks to our social media guru, Anthony. It seemed like a couple of high-schoolers and college students were quite helpful after all. While this all happened over the course of months, it feels like it was just yesterday that Scott had given me that call. It has enabled me to take part in something necessary, and now I can clearly see the magnitude of what we‚Äôre facing today, not only nationally but globally. Nevertheless, throughout the countless meetings and work sessions, it was always a pleasure to see that even after many hurdles, each one of us shared the passion to do our part. Unitedly, we contributed our talents, ideas, and professions to something, as frequently quoted, ‚Äúbigger than ourselves.‚Äù

title: Personal Growth and Financial Literacy ‚Äì How I Found my Purpose through FinMango
excerpt: by Uday Patel‚ÄúAn investment in knowledge pays the best interest.
body:
by Uday Patel

‚ÄúAn investment in knowledge pays the best interest.‚Äù This quote by Benjamin Franklin has been ingrained in me, and has been embedded in my mind since a very young age. This inspirational quote has always motivated me to address every obstacle that I‚Äôve encountered. These words have taught me how important every aspect of my life is, even if it‚Äôs the smallest thought that enters my mind.

Being raised in a country with one of the highest poverty rates in the world, this quote opened my eyes to a new way of perceiving the world. These simple, yet powerful words instilled a passion within me from a very young age, to volunteer and dedicate my time to the community to perhaps have the opportunity to see a smile on someone‚Äôs face.

Last year, I had the chance to reflect on the purpose of my life, and what would make me truly happy. I resolved that my life‚Äôs purpose was to help other people, and to help improve the environment in the most positive and innovative ways possible.‚Äù It was this purpose that brought me to FinMango.

While exploring FinMango‚Äôs web page, I ran across Anthony Schilt‚Äôs instagram page, and I was intrigued by the mission of FinMango. I saw this as a great opportunity to serve my community through data, advocacy, and technology. After speaking with Scott Glasgow, the CEO of FinMango, internally known as Mango Scott, I immediately got involved in FinMango as a Marketing and Technology intern .

My first responsibility was to work with Kishan Patel to utilize a $120,000 grant for our Google Adword campaign. I appreciated how I had the opportunity to showcase my skills, and the way Scott trusted me with every step of the way. After settling in with this project, I was given the opportunity to be co-coordinator with Kishan Patel and Anthony Schilt for the technology segment of the Extravaganza. Extravaganza was a 24-hour zoom call with 50+ keynote speakers. This event was filled with impressive and successful people who shared their stories about financial literacy.

I also had the privilege of being a moderator for one of the panels titled ‚ÄúThe Impacts of Financial Literacy on Young Professionals.‚Äù Being involved in the Extravaganza increased my knowledge about financial literacy, in addition to improving my communication and leadership skills. Several hundreds of people participated in watching these panels, challenging me to step out of my comfort zone, and invest all of my energy into making this program a success. I felt really good after being a panel moderator; this achievement reinforced in me the importance of educating a person about financial literacy. I also recognized the fact that I possibly made someone smile! I felt confident I was  impacting other people‚Äôs lives while simultaneously educating myself.

After a couple of weeks, we started to work on FinMango‚Äôs Data project. I didn‚Äôt know where this project would lead ‚Äì it has turned out to be one of the most amazing projects that I‚Äôve worked on as a member of FinMango. I am in awe of the depth of information and experience I have gained from this project, and the impact it is having on people. In the collaborative project with Google, I am the lead mango for covid data collection for South Africa with two fellow mangos, James Glasgow and Dr. Glasgow. After investing hard work at the inception of the project, including reaching out to hospitals, health departments, managers, different resources, and collecting data, we had the most reliable Covid-19 data in the world.This was an unforgettable feeling. I am grateful to Oscar Wahltinez for providing this tremendous and unique opportunity to us. The Covid-19 Data Project was the idea of Oscar Wahltinez, a Developer Programs Engineer at Google, who provided insight and guidance for our team throughout each step of the process. This project led to another avenue of data collection ‚Äì researching Covid-19 outbreaks data in K-12 schools across the United States. I was designated as the lead on this project for all K-12 schools on the east coast of the United States. I am proud to see our team gaining recognition for our work of collecting and sharing pertinent data with the world ‚Äì we have been published on CNN, The New York Times, and The Daily Beast, with (hopefully) plenty more to come.

After several weeks on the Google Data Project, the United Nations informed us that they wanted to use the data we collected. They also wanted to learn about the framework of the project in its entirety. Scott asked me if I was willing to present our project with Kishan Patel and OJ Singh in front of the UN. When I heard the news, I freaked out! I had to prepare extraneously for this presentation, which meant going out of my comfort zone, again. Nevertheless, the presentation went well, and now I can say that the biggest accomplishment in my life (so far) has been presenting in front of the UN!

So far, FinMango has been an epic journey for me; I can't wait to see what our team of mangoes will do next! I love every single one of them and look forward to continuing growing with them. FinMango helped me develop my personal drive and motivation. It helped me become someone who will never stop trying to become what they aspire to be. Our team of mangoes truly feels like my second family; an environment where everyone is encouraged to be their authentic self.

title: "Teach them how to fish"‚Äã: how will that help their finances?
excerpt: all know the oldest clich√© in development, aid or whatever subject the speaker wants this to be about: "give someone a fish, and they'll eat for a day.
body:
By Michael Gilmore

We all know the oldest clich√© in development, aid or whatever subject the speaker wants this to be about: "give someone a fish, and they'll eat for a day..."

I don't need to finish it, do I? You're already saying the second half in your head right now. It's so well known and so powerful, Mad Men-style advertising copywriters would give their Martini-holding right arms to come up with something half that resonant.

And yet. With all that power and fame, where are all the fishing lessons?

If we know that this epithet is true, and has been true ever since Lao Tzu was supposed to have originally said it, shouldn't we by now have learnt that we all need to be taught how to survive for the rest of our lives? Shouldn't we be making sure that every generation is equipped with the skills it will need?

Back in Lao Tzu's day that was probably actually fishing, but today, right now, and probably for most of the last 100 to 200 years, that should have been finance. Not necessarily "high finance" or anything complicated, but enough to understand what money really is, and how to make it work for us more than we have to work for it.

Some time back, an idle thought crossed my mind: I wonder if more people teach fishing than financial literacy, and obviously raced to google to check. Almost everywhere I searched, using different terms, different virtual locations and even different engines, the results showed that people actually do offer and search for fishing lessons more than they do financial literacy.

Yes, more of us are either looking for or offering lessons on fishing, a thing that would have been the latest and greatest thing a couple of thousand years ago, than are looking or offering to help learn how to manage the money in our lives. Which would be the greatest if not latest thing today.

The thing that makes us secure. The thing that might stop us dropping into poverty. The thing that might help us have a happy and healthy retirement. The thing that might, actually, help us "eat forever".

I re-ran the test this week on google trends, inspired by Stephen Barnham (who I failed to link here - sorry Steve), and the results are roughly the same - this time run on a global database. On the chart at the top of this post, the blue line is fishing lessons, the red one is finance lessons.

Globally, fishing lessons have been twice as popular on average as financial literacy for the last five years. Lessons for the thing that could actually dramatically change our lives have only been more popular than fishing in only a few weeks out of that period. This is insane.

It's not just fishing. Pottery lessons score 10% more than finance on google trends, and knitting, yes knitting, is only 20% less popular in the last five years! Give it a try for yourself if you've got a hobby you would like to compare: https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?date=today%205-y&q=fishing%20lessons,finance%20lessons

Despite the fact that money - or particularly the lack of it - can drive the flow of our lives, classes for understanding it are barely as popular as skills that, while charming and potentially distracting, have stopped being a viable source of income and support for most of the world in the last 50 years. And they definitely shouldn't be a source of income for people searching them on google!

If I go back to one of the things I said in my last article (https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/how-financial-literacy-could-matter-than-ever-michael-gilmore), that people don't want to be financially literate, they want to be financially stable, secure or even wealthy, then we can see the evidence for this on google too.

"Financial security" as a search term is ten times more popular than fishing lessons and 20x times more popular than finance lessons. The yellow line in the chart below is "financial security" added to the one above for fishing and finance.

People are desperate to learn how to eat forever, but because our education system doesn't tell them that understanding money is the way to achieve this, they are twice as likely to look for fishing lessons as finance ones! It's a 20-to-1 mismatch in terms of people looking for financial security and looking for financial literacy.

That people are looking for financial security is a worry - but also a relief. It is obviously sad that so many people are concerned about their financial security than so many other subjects, but in some ways it is a positive that they are at least searching for the answer. If we can create and distribute tools, products, books, apps - and maybe even a journal (https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/how-were-trying-use-our-simple-little-journal-solve-two-gilmore) - that address this gap, we can meet this demand head on and help resolve this eminently fixable problem. We can perhaps be 20x more effective if we address the demand for financial security than that for financial literacy.

The FT's new initiative  appears to me to be the most promising I have seen, and I hope to be as involved as I can be.

It could help millions of people. It could make aid programmes more efficient and education systems more relevant. It also doesn't require any great break-throughs, as everything that needs to be taught is already well-known, it just needs re-shaping to fit its audience rather than its teachers.

Let's do this! Let's take this opportunity to teach people how to really fish, how to manage their money so it helps their lives, so they can indeed eat forever.

title: FinMango in San Francisco
excerpt: This past week FinMango was invited to San Francisco to congratulate the third cohort of the Center For Financial Services Innovation‚Äôs FinLab.
body:
This past week FinMango was invited to San Francisco to congratulate the third cohort of the Center For Financial Services Innovation‚Äôs FinLab. The team was able to meet the creators of FinTech aimed to revolutionize the way people interact with their finances and experience new creative solutions to everyday financial issues.

‚ÄúThe Financial Solutions Lab is managed by the Center for Financial Services Innovation with founding partner JPMorgan Chase & Co. The Financial Solutions Lab is a program that seeks to identify, test and brings to scale promising innovations that help Americans increase savings, improve credit, and build assets.‚Äù - https://cfsinnovation.org/

Eight companies went through a program that helped to connect and grow their product with consumers and industry leaders. This year the mission was to target at-risk populations--or people who suffer from exclusion because of their financial situations. This issue has been the cornerstone to the mission of FinMango, and we could not have been more excited to hear from these eight companies on how they approached the issue of financial exclusion. Companies included:

  • Token Transit, a company aimed to fight financial exclusion through an easily accessible bus pass purchasing application from their prepaid, debit, or credit card;
  • Nova, a company that acknowledges the obstacles of immigrants building credit in the U.S. by helping share their credit history in their past country to help establish credit history;
  • Dave.com, a company that is on a mission to save you from paying overdraft fees by helping you to monitor your expenses as they come and allowing you to borrow from your next paycheck to avoid overdraft fees;
  • Grove, a company that makes comprehensive financial advisors easy to reach through technology;
  • EverSafe, a company on a mission to stop theft or financial abuse for aging Americans by creating an alert system that ends exploiters before it goes too far;
  • Tomorrow, a company hoping to make creating a will and trust as easy as possible to save Americans from unfortunate situations through a simple mobile app;
  • Point, a company that allows Americans to use the wealth in their home without taking on new debt;
  • Blueprint Income, that takes the idea of income annuity and makes it easy for anyone of any age to look forward to their retirement.

We heard from speakers and discussed with leaders that frontier the industries of FinTech to learn more about their stories, financial issues, creative solutions, and how we can integrate these solutions to the world around us.

‚ÄúThe event acted as a catalyst for the Finmango organization, giving us a new drive and direction for the future,‚Äù commented Mango Jonathan Li. We are ecstatic to bring back fresh perspectives and all that we have learned in San Francisco to push Finmango‚Äôs mission further!

title: Why I Mango - Maci Woyat
excerpt: ‚ÄúBeing Mango is standing up for equality and fairness, by empowering the people around you to take their life into their own hands with financial tools and knowledge to fund their...
body:
‚ÄúBeing Mango is standing up for equality and fairness, by empowering the people around you to take their life into their own hands with financial tools and knowledge to fund their dreams.‚Äù ‚Äî Maci Woyat

My name is Maci Woyat! As a current university student, not only am I passionate about my work inside the classroom, but I am passionate about what I can do with that knowledge I have learned to educate the world around me. My love for Finance and Economics comes from my day to day interactions I had where money was constantly flowing around me. I found myself intrigued with how money‚Äôs movement influenced decisions and society. This lead me to follow a path towards gaining my bachelors degrees in those subjects.

However, I always felt that studying inside the classroom could only get you so close to the subject. That it was almost like going to a museum and pressing your face up against the glass to study the artifact in front of you. But, to truly understand and make a difference in the world, you have to be engaged with what you are studying. So I became a Mango to learn more about economics and finance and their impacts in my community. What I learned from my work at FinMango was beyond just applying the knowledge I have been studying. I learned about what it means to make a difference in the world around me and what being a Mango truly means.

Being a Mango is acting as an advocate for financial literacy. Being a Mango is sharing the knowledge and opportunity you have been granted with the world around you. Being Mango is standing up for equality and fairness, by empowering the people around you to take their life into their own hands with financial tools and knowledge to fund their dreams. Being a Mango is doing all of this while being innovative, creative, and having fun.

I am a Mango because I want to be a catalyst for others‚Äô success stories. I have had the opportunity to learn about the financial literacy movement from my local community, all the way to Nepal or Togo (to name a few). When I hear the stories from our partners and past students of the programs, I hear proof that our work makes a difference. Being a Mango is one of the most privileged positions I have been granted, and is a constant motivation to learn more and work harder to help improve the lives of others.
